stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on a new “Egg Coin / Yoshi Coin” collection mission UI by adding a seventh act to each course that provides a Sonic Adventure–style proximity radar. He also discusses how coins will become a meaningful global currency that can change the world (e.g., funding bridges), troubleshoots a dynamic light object that refuses to spawn, and gives a quick status update on planned late-game courses and demo strategy.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a major structural/UI change (7th mission with radar) tied to collectible design and the game’s economy vision, plus a concrete engine quirk found while debugging object spawning.

findings.summary: Kaze changed the act structure from 6 to 7 missions per course; the new seventh act is explicitly “Find the Egg Coins,” framing Yoshi/Egg coin hunting as a dedicated objective rather than an optional side-collectible.
He implemented a Sonic Adventure 1–inspired radar for the seventh act: each coin gets an icon that blinks faster (and shifts toward red) as Mario approaches the coin’s location.

Kaze decided against making the radar a purchasable item because players who haven’t bought it would get no guidance in mission 7, creating a “miserable experience.” He leans toward making the radar automatic for the coin mission so nobody gets stuck due to lack of information.
findings.quote: Imagine this situation: you have not bought the radar and you're doing mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all. That's gonna suck.

findings.summary: Coins are planned to be a global currency with tangible impact; Kaze pitches funding world changes (e.g., donating 500 coins to an NPC to build a bridge), so spending alters the overworld/levels rather than being a pointless collectible.
findings.quote: Trust me, the coins are not gonna feel worthless… you're actually gonna affect the world by giving people money.

findings.summary: UI readability problems emerged: radar blinking can feel distracting, and color-coding conflicts with the fact that coin colors vary by level and there are also “collected” icon colors—creating potential confusion between radar intensity, coin color, and collected state.

Kaze explored alternative radar feedback methods (transparency that increases as you get closer, brightness/saturation shifts, pulsating halos), but noted N64-era constraints (e.g., scaling sprites looks bad because 1 texture pixel maps to 1 screen pixel).

He found why certain dynamic light objects weren’t spawning: in the SM64 engine, setting a behavior parameter value of 255 prevents the object from spawning at all, an unexpected “hidden rule” that blocked the lights’ function.
findings.quote: If you set the behParam to 255 the object does not spawn. This is so wild.

findings.summary: Demo prep status: the course he’s polishing is largely done; remaining work includes fixing/adding dynamic lights and integrating a mushroom line asset Biobak is working on.
Demo strategy: he expects crashes if players reach levels not included in the demo build; he mentions a plan for a second demo that will include only Course 1.

Progression/score design changed: “commissions do not exist anymore” and points are now global (not tied to a specific mission), implying a systemic shift away from per-star scoring toward a unified meta currency/progression layer.

High-level course planning update: all main courses are planned and each has some work done; Course 13 is an Ice Castle (outside area still unfinished), Course 14 is the Craft World (mostly done), and Course 15 is a Space Arcade (described as more of a pathway currently).
Rumble Pack support is currently disabled; Kaze says implementing it would require a separate thread and he can’t test it because he doesn’t own a Rumble Pak.

He references a report about someone being “struck” (copyright/strike issue) and says he’s confident it was done by an imposter, indicating ongoing vigilance about bad-faith strikes in the community ecosystem around the project.
Kaze actively incorporates chat feedback on the radar UI (e.g., suggestions about distraction, alternative indicators, and transparency), using stream iteration as a design review loop.

biobak.summary: Biobak is working on a “line of mushrooms” asset/placement for the demo course that Kaze plans to integrate, indicating parallel asset production feeding into Kaze’s level assembly.

zeina.summary: Zeina appears on stream briefly (“in the house”), reflecting the informal, at-home dev environment; Kaze also mentions coordinating with her about potentially picking up a second N64 (logistical support for dev/testing).

findings.summary: Lilaa is referenced during discussion of missing/spawning lights and the coin system; the mention suggests ongoing community feedback/bug awareness even if the exact chat message isn’t fully captured by the transcript.
Davy’s suggestion about radar/indicator behavior is acknowledged while Kaze experiments with transparency-based feedback; also noted via a resubscription.

key_stories.title: Turning Yoshi/Egg coin hunting into a dedicated 7th mission with a radar
key_stories.summary: Kaze introduces a structural change to course act-select: a seventh mission dedicated to finding Egg Coins. He builds a Sonic Adventure–style proximity radar to make this hunt readable and less frustrating, then debates whether the radar should be a purchasable upgrade or guaranteed for the mission.
key_stories.challenge: Coin-hunting without guidance risks being frustrating, especially if players don’t know a radar exists or haven’t bought it; meanwhile, excessive UI cues can ruin the “treasure hunt” feel.
key_stories.process: He prototypes the radar (blinking rate/intensity by distance), considers the economic implications of buying vs. default access, and iterates on alternative UI feedback (slower blinking, transparency, brightness) to reduce distraction and avoid color-confusion with level-specific coin colors and collected-state icons.
key_stories.outcome: Direction shifts toward making the radar automatically available during the coin mission to prevent an “unhinted” miserable experience; UI refinements (e.g., transparency/less distracting pulsing) remain under evaluation.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine this situation: you have not bought the radar and you're doing mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all. That's gonna suck.

key_stories.title: Dynamic lights not spawning due to a hidden behavior parameter rule
key_stories.summary: While polishing the demo course, Kaze investigates why certain dynamic light objects do not appear despite being placed and active for the act. He isolates the cause to an engine-level quirk tied to an object parameter value.
key_stories.challenge: Placed lights exist in the scene but their function doesn’t run; they simply refuse to spawn, blocking intended atmosphere/visual polish for the demo area.
key_stories.process: He inspects object settings/behavior and eventually identifies a specific SM64 engine rule: behParam value 255 prevents object spawning.
key_stories.outcome: Root cause found; he can now avoid/adjust the offending parameter to restore dynamic lights in the demo build.
key_stories.key_quote: If you set the behParam to 255 the object does not spawn.

key_stories.title: Making coins matter through world-changing purchases
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains that coins will be more than a completion metric: they’ll function as a global currency used for upgrades and changing the environment. He gives an example of donating large sums to NPC projects that alter the overworld (like building a bridge).
key_stories.challenge: Collectibles risk feeling pointless unless they tie into meaningful progression or world interaction, especially in a Mario 64-style structure where stars already drive progress.
key_stories.process: He outlines a system where players spend accumulated coins on upgrades or contributions, causing permanent or semi-permanent changes to the world.
key_stories.outcome: A clear design pillar emerges: coins are intended to feel valuable and impactful—potentially more so than comparable modern Mario collectibles.
key_stories.key_quote: You're actually gonna affect the world by giving people money.
